{{Other people|James Dobbin}} {{Infobox US Cabinet official | name=James Cochran Dobbin | image=JCDobbin.jpg | order1=22nd | title1=[[United States Secretary of the Navy]] | term_start1=March 8, 1853 | term_end1=March 4, 1857 | president1=[[Franklin Pierce]] | predecessor1=[[John P. Kennedy]] | successor1=[[Isaac Toucey]] | state2=[[North Carolina]] | district2={{ushr|North Carolina|5|5th}} | term_start2=March 4, 1845 | term_end2=March 3, 1847 | predecessor2=[[Romulus M. Saunders]] | successor2=[[Abraham Watkins Venable|Abraham W. Venable]] | office3 = Member of the [[North Carolina House of Commons]] | term3 = 1848
1850
1852 | birth_date={{birth date|1814|1|17|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Fayetteville, North Carolina]], US | death_date={{death date and age|1857|8|4|1814|1|17}} | death_place=[[Fayetteville, North Carolina]], US | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | spouse= | alma_mater=[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] | profession=Politician, Lawyer | religion= }} '''James Cochran Dobbin''' (January 17, 1814 – August 4, 1857) was a nineteenth-century politician and lawyer who served as [[United States Secretary of the Navy]] from 1853 to 1857. Born in [[Fayetteville, North Carolina]] in 1814, the grandson of [[congressman]] [[James Cochran (North Carolina)|James Cochran]], Dobbin attended Fayetteville Academy and the William Bingham School and later went on to graduate from the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|University of North Carolina]] in 1832. While at Carolina, Dobbin distinguished himself as a member of [[The Dialectic and Philanthropic Societies|Philanthropic Assembly]]. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1835, commencing practice in Fayetteville. Dobbin later got involved in politics and was elected a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[29th United States Congress|twenty-ninth congress]], serving from 1845 to 1847. He later served in the [[North Carolina House of Commons]] in 1848, 1850 and 1852, also serving as [[Speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives|speaker of the house]] in 1850. In 1852, he was a delegate to the [[Democratic National Convention]] where he helped secure the nomination of [[Dark horse|dark horse candidate]] [[Franklin Pierce]] for the [[President of the United States|presidency]]. Pierce appointed Dobbin [[United States Secretary of the Navy]] as a reward for his work in the presidential campaign. A firm believer in a strong [[United States Navy|Navy]] as an insurance for [[peace]], Dobbin instituted reforms throughout the Navy. Eighteen of the finest ships of their class in the world were built during his tenure as Navy secretary. Under his auspices, the Perry expedition to Japan was carried to a successful termination and the treaty with that country signed. He ordered U.S. Navy Lieutenant [[Isaac Strain]] to command a U.S. Darién Exploring Expedition to map and survey the [[Darién Gap]] for a [[Panama Canal]] to link the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] and Pacific Oceans. After his term as Navy secretary expired in 1857, Dobbin returned to Fayetteville where he eventually died later that year. He was interred at [[Cross Creek Cemetery]] in Fayetteville. The ''[[USS Dobbin (AD-3)]]'', a ship present at the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|attack of Pearl Harbor]] on December 7, 1941, was named in his honor. ==External links== {{CongBio|D000381}} *[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8056745 James C. Dobbin] at [[Find A Grave]] {{NHC}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=North Carolina | district=5 | before=[[Romulus Mitchell Saunders|Romulus M. Saunders]] | after= [[Abraham Watkins Venable|Abraham W. Venable]] | years=March 4, 1845 – March 3, 1847 }} {{s-gov}} {{succession box | before= [[John P. Kennedy]] | title= [[United States Secretary of the Navy]] | years= March 8, 1853 – March 4, 1857 | after= [[Isaac Toucey]]}} {{s-end}} {{USSecNavy}} {{Pierce cabinet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dobbin, James C.}} [[Category:1814 births]] [[Category:1857 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from North Carolina]] [[Category:United States Secretaries of the Navy]] [[Category:Members of the North Carolina House of Representatives]] [[Category:North Carolina lawyers]] [[Category:Pierce administration cabinet members]] [[Category:North Carolina Democrats]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill alumni]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]
